title: Class action law suit vs Roit games.
body:
Okay,

So here is the deal. I have been ban for supposed scripting. Knowing I have done nothing wrong and after contacting support with multiple support tickets. Informing Riot that there was unsual activity on my account and being constantly replied to with copy and paste messages I have decided to start a class action law suit against riot games in hopes that they will stop over looking matters and take action.

I have been constantly told that scripts were detected with no evedence of a single game where scrips were used to gain an unfair advantage. I have not had anyone actually look into the matter because I am sure that if they did they will see no games has scripts used. 

Riot is claiming they were detected yet as we all know there system from time to time does make mistakes. The last ban wave many accounts were wrongly ban and riot has admitted to this. So clearly there system can make mistakes. I will be contacting a law firm on Monday to in hopes that Riot ups there game and there support team stops over looking ever ticket and sending generic copy and paste messages without actually looking into it at all!

If you are toxic they will send you the chat log proving you were toxic yet in my case they can not provide any evedence of any rules being broken other then something was detected by there systems. As we all now know there systems make mistakes. Vote and comment so I can get numbers as to how many people will join me on this fight vs riot games!


On a side note.

It is not hard to do and really you wont have to do much. I started one not long ago due to the fact the area where I lived had no internet or phone phone provisions and within 1 month guess what.... We now have access to internet after 1 year without it. So it is not something difficult to do. Though please only say yes if you were actually wronged. If you done something that god you ban take the ban but if you didn't then join me!

But again we won't know, because there are neither evidences here suggesting either you're right or wrong, similarly the same goes for Riot in this particular case.

They intentionally do not disclose anything regarding cheat bans because that would be the same as giving cheaters feedbacks about how fix their cheats to eventually get around the system. Any system can be hacked and broken, it's all a matter of time, hence Riot dragging it out is not something that's wrong or uncommon; hell, Valve doesn't tell you anything when you're VAC'ed either, it pretty much only says "hey you're banned, good luck elsewhere asshole".

You can't simply assume people to all jump onto your side just because you're presenting yourself to be the David in this scenario. You have to prove it for it to really work.

The customer service is only there to handle customer complaints and other service related things (such as account and billing management). They are supposed to pass on the review request onto the said higher-up so the case can be investigated, which they will, and then the customer service will get back to the player if there's any development.

During case review upon request, they generally will look much more in-depth than the automatic system would (look into such as past in-game history and pattern, IP location and access behaviour etc; not BS'ing, they actually do).

If you're not happy with the copy-and-paste responses, know that they merely use it out of efficiency reasons. And that they're only replying you with the same thing over and over most likely because there is just no new development, ie, either it's still in the process of investigation or that they've still determined that you cheated hence there is nothing they want to chat to you with. Make it what you will.

Im not sure wether this is legit, or is a bluff to spark some attention from Riot to your problem.

But I'm afraid it isn't going to work.

If you haven't read the terms and conditions of the game, I would strongly suggest you do so, especially before pouring money into a law suit. 
It clearly states in the terms and conditions that Riot owns your account and any items purchased on it. It is their property not yours, AND that they have the right to suspend your account for "Any or **NO** reason."

So you physically cant touch them, because they have not stepped outside the terms and conditions. Your mistake is assuming that your account belongs to you, and that you have any right to it. 

Riot could legally ban the entire server for no reason if they wanted, and have no legal repercussions, according to the terms and conditions you agreed to.
Just imagine if Real Life Stores had those rights, It would be ridiculous.

* A restaurant has the right to kick out and deny any customer service for no reason if they so choose, as long as the driving force behind it is not rooted in discrimination. It would be bad PR, but it's not technically illegal.
* A restaurant's seat is not owned by the customer just because they're using it for dinner, it's still the property of the restaurant and just a platform of which the customer interacts and conducts businesses with the said restaurant.
* A restaurant would have a set of rules in which it expects the customers to follow, otherwise the customer might get blacklisted and thrown out.

etc etc.

Doesn't matter if it's the goods that can be taken away like restaurant or real estate, or virtual such as cinema or Netflix, they all have roughly the same or equivalent deals as listed above.

Not so ridiculous now isn't it?

I mean this isn't really an accurate scenario to what i was implying.

Imagine Kmart had these rules, and could kick you out simply because someone was offended by you picking your nose, and not only that but ban you from the store AND go to your house and repo all the items you ever bought from there.

What your listing is actually nothing in common other then the other virtual media's (which might i add, Netflix actually encourages multiple people using the service, because people are more likely to get their own for convenience, but that isn't the point)

Both Real Estate and Restaurant's are different, but for the Real Estate one, it would be like if someone was offended by you AFTER you bought your house, and took back the deed because of it.

The significant difference is that we aren't talking about Small amounts of money (like a single meal/Getting taken out of a rental/losing your bond) we are talking about the larger end of money in any platform (because it's not just what you have bought recently, but what you bought for the entirety of being here)

You do realise that 1) This particular case has nothing to do with offending people but about cheating and 2) Riot only hands out behaviour bans in severe cases of misbehaviour and not every little thing, right? I mean, why does the community always have these contradictory narratives that simultaneously claim that the punish system overly bans people and not banning people at all at the same time? But I digress.

You also do realise the reason why Riot "takes away" your stuff after you're blacklisted is simply because that the goods are virtual, directly integrated into their infrastructure, and completely irrelevant if not used on Riot's service, right? 

To draw parallels, it would be the same as say having a house which you spent money decorating it (here let's pretend the decoration service is state-owned). And after some incident, such as you're found out to idk, deal drugs or getting into trouble with the community continuously or something, you would get run out of and thus lose your house, and whatever that decoration you'd worked on it is also lost naturally. The account is the same thing. It's not that Riot intentionally takes away your things after the account bans, it's that the service and goods are directly connected and losing one also means losing the other by nature.

EDIT: This is the same for say, Steam, where if your Steam account itself is banned, all of your games accessible via that account are also no longer reachable. This is also the same as say paid TV channels (though one can not interact with others via TV so access can't be banned via misconduct). The service is to provide access, not to provide ownership.

I get that the misbehaviour i said wasn't accurate, trying to focus on that specifically is moving away from the point.

And the issue is that if we are trying to draw exact parallels then it's.

1) You get banned from a store, and everything gets repo'd.
2) You can re-enter the store, if you simply give them a different username (as in this store you don't use your name but a username).

Any store attempting this method would quickly be boycotted whether any bans were justified or not, because it would be seen as a cash grab attempt.

There are more than 1 type of service platforms than your local grocery store. When the goods are inseparable from the main infrastructure of the said service, a service operates under the goal of providing customers access to the goods rather than selling the goods' ownership.

Riot can NOT give your purchased champs or skins in a bag, it's not some takeaway food as it's completely virtual with a virtual existence on a virtual platform like a purchased emoticon on Facebook or something. The only "physical" thing in this entire trade is the account of the customer, and thus their goods are tied to it.

But when the user is denied access of the service due to breach of rules such as misbehaviour or egregious act of hacking, by the virtue of the account being a shared entity with the goods purchased itself, the goods are also no longer accessible along with the loss of the account. And it's only natural.

As I've said, this is the same deal with Steam in my Edit, if your Steam account itself is banned (not just VAC'ed, the account itself is banned), all of the games on it are lost for the same reasons as here in League. They are not going to send a physical copy of the games to your mailing address because that's not what you'd traded for during the businesses with them.

EDIT: Also Riot can not stop people from making multiple accounts, because unlike in Korea or something, your game account is not tied to your actual personal identity. That and, Riot is very indecisive when it comes to whether or not they should allow the players to reform (a lot happened you see). But then again, I don't think Riot actively encourages players to come back into the game to spend more money after perma ban to begin with (as afaik their copy-paste response to perma ban is usually "we will not lift the ban, I hope you behave well in the next game you've decided to play") so personally I don't see that much issue tbh.

Unfortunately a class action lawsuit probably wouldn't work.

This is an excerpt from the EULA that you agree to when you patch the game

>You further acknowledge and agree that you shall have no ownership or other property interest in your Account, and you acknowledge and agree that all rights in and to the Account are and shall forever be owned by and inure to the benefit of Riot Games.

This line basically gives them the right to do whatever they want in these sorts of scenarios.

That said, i did notice that the EULA has an issue in it, that the closest thing to "you are not allowed to script" is

>H. Participating in any action which, in the sole and exclusive judgment of Riot Games, “exploits” an undocumented aspect of the Game in order to secure an unfair advantage over other users

Which i have to say is really shittily worded, and seems more like "you won't abuse bugs" then "you won't script", which if that held up in court (by some way shape or form) would actually mean anyone banned in the previous ban wave get off freely and have to be unbanned.

> Unfortunately a class action lawsuit probably wouldn't work.

Agreed. Not considering the fact that Riot is a massive company, capable of hiring as many lawyers as they need, you wouldn't really have any sufficient evidence of your innocence unless you were able to "record" all actions that were performed on the computer you were using at the time the software was (supposedly) detected, and without getting certain bits of information from Riot there's no way to know when that was.

Point being, it's not worth sinking your money into something like this when you could just go play a vastly superior game.

> That said, i did notice that the EULA has an issue in it, that the closest thing to "you are not allowed to script" is
> 
> H. Participating in any action which, in the sole and exclusive judgment of Riot Games, “exploits” an undocumented aspect of the Game in order to secure an unfair advantage over other users

I don't know how much of the EULA you read, but I'd say that this qualifies as "you are not allowed to script":
> **III. Additional License Limitations**
> You agree that you will not, under any circumstances:
> ...
> E. Use any unauthorized third-party programs that interact with the Software in any way, including but not limited to, “mods,” “hacks,” “cheats,” “scripts,” “bots,” “trainers,” or automation programs, or any third-party programs that intercept, emulate or redirect any communication between the Software and Riot Games, or that collect information about the Game by reading areas of memory used by the Software to store information about the Game.
Ok then, apparently they put that in the wrong spot then, because that really isn't a license limitation but whatever.
